entry.title: Life Insurance GLM with H2O: Part 1
entry.summary:
Here I will show you how to use generalised linear models (GLM) with mortality claims data. We will fit a poisson GLM to model count data using the h2o package. This post will cover:

  • Preparing data
  • Basic h2o functions
  • Use of offsets
  • Fitting a basic GLM
  • Extracting a rating plan from the model

This article will be split into two parts - part 1 will cover the above and part 2 will cover cross validation and 'tuning' a GLM using h2o's grid search functionality. Finally, in a later post we will look at how to build simple pricing apps using the models we develop.

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Here I will show you how to use generalised linear models (GLM) with mortality claims data. We will fit a poisson GLM to model count data using the h2o package. This post will cover:</p>
<ul>
<li>Preparing data</li>
<li>Basic h2o functions</li>
<li>Use of offsets</li>
<li>Fitting a basic GLM</li>
<li>Extracting a rating plan from the model</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This article will be split into two parts - part 1 will cover the above and part 2 will cover cross validation and 'tuning' a GLM using h2o's grid search functionality. Finally, in a later post we will look at how to build simple pricing apps using the models we develop.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Background">Background<a class="anchor-link" href="#Background">¶</a></h2><p>Imagine a portfolio of lives with lump sum death benefit cover - we want to be able to model how many claims will arise from this portfolio. The number of claims will obviously vary depending on how long each life has insurance cover in place.</p>
<p>GLMs are widely used by actuaries to set rating plans that are used to price insurance products - particularly in general insurance (personal lines etc). One of the benefits of using GLMs is that it's usually easy to extract an interpretable, often simple, rating plan from the model (this is discussed in more detail later). A GLM also allows us to update an existing rating plan rather than set an entirely new one. An existing rating plan may have been set, for example, using standard tables.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Data">Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Data">¶</a></h2><p>I'll use a simulated dataset created <a href="https://josho88.github.io/Simulating%20Data.html">in a previous post</a>. This dataset contains 1.5m records. Each record represents an individual and the columns contain their age, gender, occupation, location, salary details, exposure (how long, in years, the individual was insured) and whether or not a claim was made under their policy. To create this dataset you can follow the previous <a href="https://josho88.github.io/Simulating%20Data.html">tutorial</a> or alternatively any similar dataset should be fine.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Read in the data</span>
dt <span class="o">=</span> read.csv<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'SimData.csv'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>

</div>

<div class="inner_cell">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Import-Libraries">Import Libraries<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Libraries">¶</a></h2><p>The h2o package will be used extensively. Dplyr will also be needed. Import these libraries using the following commands:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>h2o<span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>dplyr<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In order to use h2o functions, we need to initialise an h2o cluster. Use the <code>h2o.init()</code> function. For example:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>h2o.init<span class="p">(</span>nthreads <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">-1</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># convert data to h2o frame</span>
h2o_data <span class="o">=</span> as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Existing-Plan">Existing Plan<a class="anchor-link" href="#Existing-Plan">¶</a></h2><p>Often, a rating plan is already in place and rather than start from scratch we may just want to add to (or update) this existing model. For example, we might already have a best estimate of claim rates for the general population which aren't being updated as part of this exercise, but we want to use the GLM to refine these rates. In this example I'll define the existing estimate of claim rates to be:</p>
<ul>
<li>Individuals under 40 will be assumed, on average, to claim at a rate of $\frac{1}{1000}$</li>
<li>Individuals aged 40-49 have a claim rate of $\frac{1.5}{1000}$</li>
<li>Ages 50 + have a claim rate of $\frac{2}{1000}$</li>
</ul>
<p>These baseline rates vary by age but not gender, occupation and so on. The GLM can be used to refine these initial estimates so that the final predicted claim count allows for our other predictor variables.</p>
<p>Next, we need to add these base rates to each record. Of course, each individual won't necessarily have been the same age for the entire period they were covered under a policy! However, for simplicity here I'm going to assume that age is the average age over the exposure period and just set our best estimate of mortality based on this average age. In reality, a more realistic expectation of mortality may be used - based on age varying over the exposure period.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span>ages <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">as.vector</span><span class="p">(</span>h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Age_Last<span class="p">)</span>
Base_Rate <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">ifelse</span><span class="p">(</span>ages <span class="o">%in%</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">0</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="m">39</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="m">0.001</span><span class="p">,</span>
            <span class="kp">ifelse</span><span class="p">(</span>ages <span class="o">%in%</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">40</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="m">49</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="m">0.0015</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="m">0.002</span><span class="p">))</span>
h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Base_Rate <span class="o">=</span> h2o.asnumeric<span class="p">(</span>as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>Base_Rate<span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>To allow for these base rates in the GLM model an offset column needs to be added.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Adding-an-Offset-Column">Adding an Offset Column<a class="anchor-link" href="#Adding-an-Offset-Column">¶</a></h2><p>An offset is a covariate in the model with a coefficient constrained to be one (rather than being estimated). In this model, we need to add two offsets - one to allow for exposure and one to allow for the fact that we do not wish to update our base rates as part of this process.</p>
<h3 id="Why-use-an-offset-to-allow-for-exposure?">Why use an offset to allow for exposure?<a class="anchor-link" href="#Why-use-an-offset-to-allow-for-exposure?">¶</a></h3><p>Mathematically, the poisson model takes the form:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>However, since our response variable is actually claims per unit of exposure, we are modelling a rate. Which takes the form:</p>
<p>$$log(\frac{\mu}{exposure}) = \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>This is equivalent to:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) - log(exposure) = \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>Finally, $log(exposure)$ enters the right hand side of the equation as an offset with coefficient constrained to one, giving:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = log(exposure) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<h3 id="Why-use-an-offset-for-base-rates?">Why use an offset for base rates?<a class="anchor-link" href="#Why-use-an-offset-for-base-rates?">¶</a></h3><p>As mentioned earlier, our base rates are derived outside of this model and are not being updated here. However, these base rates will still form part of the overall rating plan and so the GLM model needs to be made aware of them. The other loadings will be optimised once our base rates have been applied. Therefore, base_rate enters the RHS of the equation as follows:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = log(exposure) + log(base\_rate) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>And since $log(a) + log(b) = log(ab)$ this can be simplified as:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = log(exposure\times base\_rate) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>Which is equivalent to:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = log(\mathbb{E}[deaths]) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>Therefore, the final offset to be included in the model is $log(\mathbb{E}[deaths])$</p>
<p>So, next we need to calculate $\mathbb{E}[deaths]$ for each record. This will be our base rate multiplied by the exposure period. Then the data can be split into train, test and holdout sets and the offset columns are added.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Calculate the 'expected deaths' for each record</span>
h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Expected_Deaths <span class="o">=</span> h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Exposure <span class="o">*</span> h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Base_Rate
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># First, set Occupation and Location variables as nominal factor variables</span>
<span class="c1"># (salary band isn't strictly nominal but we'll treat it as such here)</span>
h2o_data<span class="p">[</span><span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'Occupation'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Location'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Salary_Band'</span><span class="p">)]</span> <span class="o">=</span>
    h2o.asfactor<span class="p">(</span>h2o_data<span class="p">[</span><span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'Occupation'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Location'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Salary_Band'</span><span class="p">)])</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Separate into a train, test and holdout set</span>
<span class="c1"># 60% in training and 20% in test & holdout respectively</span>
split <span class="o">=</span> h2o.splitFrame<span class="p">(</span>h2o_data<span class="p">,</span> ratios <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">0.6</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">0.2</span><span class="p">),</span> seed <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">123</span><span class="p">)</span>
train <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">split</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">]]</span>
test <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">split</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="m">2</span><span class="p">]]</span>
holdout <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">split</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="m">3</span><span class="p">]]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Since the dataset is large and the claim event is rare I am going to reduce the datasets using aggregation. In the aggregated datasets each row will represent a feature set and the claims and exposure columns will be the sum of all claims/exposure in that given set. In practice, for a poisson GLM it doesn't make a difference to the model whether we use aggregated or full individual data.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Define a helper function to aggregate the train, test and holdout sets</span>

agg <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kr">function</span><span class="p">(</span>h2o_frame<span class="p">){</span>
  dat <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">as.data.frame</span><span class="p">(</span>h2o_frame<span class="p">)</span>
  agg_data <span class="o">=</span> aggregate<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> dat<span class="p">[</span><span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'Exposure'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s">'Claim'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s">'Expected_Deaths'</span><span class="p">)],</span>

                                 Location <span class="o">=</span> dat<span class="o">$</span>Location<span class="p">,</span>
                                 Salary_Band <span class="o">=</span> dat<span class="o">$</span>Salary_Band<span class="p">),</span>
                       FUN <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">sum</span><span class="p">)</span>
  agg_data
<span class="p">}</span>

<span class="c1"># create aggregated versions of datasets</span>
train_aggregated <span class="o">=</span> as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>agg<span class="p">(</span>train<span class="p">))</span>
test_aggregated <span class="o">=</span> as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>agg<span class="p">(</span>test<span class="p">))</span>
holdout_aggregated <span class="o">=</span> as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>agg<span class="p">(</span>holdout<span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>

<h2 id="Fitting-the-GLM">Fitting the GLM<a class="anchor-link" href="#Fitting-the-GLM">¶</a></h2><p>The GLM will be built using the h2o package. First, define the set of predictors we will use and the name of the column to be used as an offset. Then, the model is fit using <code>h2o.glm()</code>. Be careful to define the 'family' as poisson. Setting lambda = 0 means that this baseline model will not apply any regularisation. To check the performance against holdout data use <code>h2o.performance()</code>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [16]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Fit a basic GLM - with NO regularisation (discussed in part 2)</span>
<span class="c1"># Need to set alpha = 0 and lambda = 0 as h2o uses regularisation by default.</span>
<span class="c1"># Setting these to 0 overrides this.</span>

predictors <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'Salary_Band'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Occupation'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Location'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Male'</span><span class="p">)</span>
response <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'Claim'</span>
offset <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'Offset'</span>

mod1 <span class="o">=</span> h2o.glm<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> predictors<span class="p">,</span>
               y <span class="o">=</span> response<span class="p">,</span>
               training_frame <span class="o">=</span> train_aggregated<span class="p">,</span>
               validation_frame <span class="o">=</span> test_aggregated<span class="p">,</span>
               family <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'poisson'</span><span class="p">,</span>
               offset_column <span class="o">=</span> offset<span class="p">,</span>
               alpha <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span>lambda <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span>
               intercept <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">TRUE</span><span class="p">,</span>
               compute_p_values <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">TRUE</span><span class="p">,</span>
               seed <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">123</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Extracting-the-Ratings">Extracting the Ratings<a class="anchor-link" href="#Extracting-the-Ratings">¶</a></h2><p>To set a rating plan we need to extract the coefficient estimates from the model and convert these to ratings. Since the poisson GLM uses a log link function we can get to the final ratings by taking exponentials of both sides of the GLM equation. For example, to derive $\mu$ our equation becomes:</p>
<p>$$\mu = \exp(log(\mathbb{E}[deaths]) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n) $$</p>
<p>Which is equivalent to:</p>
<p>$$\mu = \mathbb{E}[deaths] \times \exp(\alpha) \times \exp(\beta_1 x_1) \times \exp(\beta_2 x_2) \times ... \times \exp(\beta_n x_n)$$</p>
<p>We can see that the final rating plan will therefore be multiplicative.</p>
</div>

<span class="c1"># (some rounding has been applied using dplyr mutate function)</span>
